Fig. 6 Electrodeposited NiMoP coating on Cu nanorods array as efficient bifunctional electrocatalysts for urea-assisted hydrogen production Mi Wang Writing – original draft Visualization Investigation Data curation a Guangqin Chen Writing – original draft Validation Investigation Formal analysis a Yan Zhang Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources b Jian Xiao Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Resources Project administration Methodology a ⁎ a School of Chemical Engineering and Pharmacy, Key Laboratory of Novel Biomass-Based Environmental and Energy Materials in Petroleum and Chemical Industry, Wuhan Institute of Technology, Wuhan, Hubei Province 430205, China School of Chemical Engineering and Pharmacy, Key Laboratory of Novel Biomass-Based Environmental and Energy Materials in Petroleum and Chemical Industry, Wuhan Institute of Technology Wuhan Hubei Province 430205 China School of Chemical Engineering and Pharmacy, Key Laboratory of Novel Biomass-Based Environmental and Energy Materials in Petroleum and Chemical Industry, Wuhan Institute of Technology, Wuhan, 430205, Hubei Province, China b Department of Bioengineering and Food Science, Hubei University of Technology, Wuhan, Hubei Province 430068, China Department of Bioengineering and Food Science, Hubei University of Technology Wuhan Hubei Province 430068 China Department of Bioengineering and Food Science, Hubei University of Technology, Wuhan, 430068, Hubei Province, China ⁎ Corresponding author. The development of bifunctional electrocatalyst for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and urea oxidation reaction (UOR) with high catalytic activity and excellent stability can promote the application of hydrogen production by urea electrolysis. In this work, a three-dimensional composite heterogeneous electrocatalyst composed of NiMoP coating on Cu nanorods array on Cu foam (CF@Cu/NiMoP) is designed and synthesized. The CuO nanorods array constructed on Cu foam was used as the substrate for electrodeposition of NiMoP layer, while CuO substrate was reduced to Cu nanorods. The optimal deposition time was 20 min in both HER and UOR processes. Because the hierarchical nanorods array structure offers abundant active sites, accelerates electron transfer kinetics, and enables efficient multi-channel transport of electrolytes and gaseous byproducts, the optimized CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 has excellent HER and UOR performances with requiring only −94.9 mV and 1.395 V, respectively, to drive 100 mA cm−2. In addition, the overall urea-electrolysis system with CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 as bifunctional electrode provides 100 mA cm−2 at a remarkably low cell voltage of 1.596 V. This energy-efficient performance can be readily powered by a commercially available mercury-free alkaline battery. Graphical Abstract Hierarchical NiMoP modified Cu nanorods array on Cu foam is prepared and shows perfect catalytic activity toward both UOR and HER in urea-oxidation-assisted electrolytic water splitting. Keywords Electrocatalysis Hydrogen evolution reaction Urea oxidation reaction Electrodeposition Nickel molybdenum phosphide Nanorods array structure Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Electrocatalytic water splitting powered by renewable energy offers a sustainable pathway to produce clean, high-purity hydrogen [1–3]. However, the overall energy efficiency of this method is significantly hampered by the anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER), which possesses inherently sluggish reaction kinetics and high theoretical potential requirement (1.23 V vs. RHE) [4–6]. In order to lower the energy cost, replacing OER with a more thermodynamically favorable organic oxidation reaction is an incentive method [7,8]. The urea oxidation reaction (UOR: CO(NH2)2+ 6OH-→N2+5H2O+CO2+ 6e-) has an incredibly low theoretical potential of 0.37 V, making it an alternative for achieving efficient hydrogen production [9–12]. And urea is a stable, non-toxic, easy to obtain, easy to store and inexpensive solid compound. Furthermore, UOR can alleviate the dilemma of urea-rich wastewater pollution, and its products CO2 and N2 can hinder the production of explosive mixtures of H2 and O2. However, the UOR, involving a complex six-electron transfer process and the generation of multiple gaseous products, faces significant challenges due to its inherently sluggish kinetics, even though it operates at a low thermodynamic potential [13]. These limitations underscore the critical need for developing highly efficient electrocatalysts to optimize UOR for energy-efficient hydrogen production. Transition metal phosphides (TMP), including nickel phosphide, have been widely concerned because of their excellent catalytic activity, good electrical conductivity, stability and low price [14,15]. In hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) process, the phosphorus and metal sites in TMP act as proton and hydroxyl receptors respectively, thus promoting hydrolytic dissociation and showing excellent catalytic activity [16,17]. Furthermore, nickel-based electrocatalysts, such as nickel alloy, nickel-based sulfides and nickel-based phosphide, are the most studied UOR catalyst materials due to their low cost and the extremely high catalytic activity of in situ generated Ni3+ species on the surface [18,19]. The performance of TMPs can be further improved by doping or alloying with other metal [20,21]. In other words, bimetallic phosphide has better adjustability and catalytic activity than mono-metallic phosphide. First, the use of bimetals can improve the electrical conductivity and increase the exposure of the active site. Secondly, the synergistic effect between bimetals can regulate the electronic structure of the catalyst, thus optimizing the intermediate energy barrier in HER or UOR process. For example, Zhang’s group reported the successful synthesis of nickel foam supporting oxygen-incorporated NiMoP nanotubes array (O-NiMoP/NF) as bifunctional UOR and HER electrocatalysts by simple electrodeposition and in situ template etching [22]. Density functional theory analysis demonstrates that neighboring O, P, and Mo atoms in O-NiMoP synergistically enhance the catalytic efficiency of Ni active sites, thus significantly promoting water molecule dissociation during HER while simultaneously optimizing intermediate conversion kinetics in UOR. In terms of electrode structure, the electrocatalyst in-situ grown on conductive substrate to form a nanoarray structure can fully expose the active site, thereby improving the catalytic performance [23–26]. It can also form a three-dimensional structure of catalyst-electrolyte contact to avoid the strong impact of gas release during the electrolysis process, which will destroy the bond between the catalyst and the conductive substrate, resulting in a significant decrease in catalyst activity and poor stability. Cu foam has emerged as a critical substrate material in advanced catalytic and electronic applications due to its exceptional electrical conductivity, cost-effectiveness, and unique surface reactivity. Notably, under electrochemical conditions, the Cu foam surface undergoes in situ oxidation to form nanostructured copper oxide arrays (e.g., Cu(OH)2 or CuO), which can subsequently be reduced back to metallic Cu during cathodic polarization [27]. This redox-driven transformation not only regenerates the conductive Cu framework but also generates oxygen-deficient interfaces and metastable defects, both of which are known to enhance charge transfer kinetics and catalytic activity [27,28]. Based on the above analysis, a three-dimensional composite heterogeneous electrocatalyst consisting of NiMoP coating on Cu nanorods array on Cu foam (CF@Cu/NiMoP) is prepared here for urea-assisted hydrogen production. First, CuO nanorods array was constructed on Cu foam (CF) collector by anodic oxidation and annealing treatment, and then CF@Cu/NiMoP electrode was successfully prepared by electrodepositing NiMoP directly on CuO nanorods array, which was simultaneously reduced to Cu nanorods array. Then, the morphology, phase structure, elemental composition and valence state of the prepared electrode were studied by various characterization techniques, and the electrocatalytic performance of the catalytic electrode was also deeply investigated. Thanks to the special nanorod structure, the optimal CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 exhibits excellent HER, OER and UOR performances. Specifically, in 1.0 M KOH, the CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode achieves 100 mA cm−2 with remarkably low overpotentials of 94.9 mV for HER and 384 mV for OER. When operating in 1.0 M KOH with 0.5 M urea for UOR, the electrode attains the same current density at a low potential of 1.395 V, representing 218 mV reduction compared to conventional OER requirements. Notably, the bifunctional catalyst enables an integrated urea-electrolysis system to deliver 100 mA cm−2 at a low cell voltage of 1.596 V, which can be powered directly by standard mercury-free alkaline batteries. This study provides strong support for the design of HER/UOR bifunctional electrocatalysts with excellent performance. 2 Experimental sections 2.1 The preparation of CF@CuO First, a Cu(OH)2 nanorods array on CF (CF@Cu(OH)2) is prepared by using anodic oxidation technique [29]. In this process, the anode material is Cu foam, the electrolyte is 1 M KOH, and an anode current density of 10 mA cm−2 is applied for 900 s. Second, the CF@Cu(OH)2 precursor is heated in a muffle furnace at 250 °C for 2 h to obtain the target CF@CuO electrode. 2.2 The synthesis of CF@Cu/NiMoP The NiMoP layer is synthesized on CF@CuO by electrodeposition technique. During this process, CF@CuO serves as the cathode material, and the electrolyte consists of 70 mL of water containing 3.680 g of NiSO4, 1.113 g of NaH2PO2, 0.677 g of Na2MoO4, and 6.176 g of sodium citrate. A cathode current density of 50 mA cm−2 is applied for 20 min. To investigate the impact of electrodeposition time on catalytic activity, the electrodeposition time varies from 5 min to 40 min. The resultant electrodes corresponding to different electrodeposition times are named CF@Cu/NiMoP-5, CF@Cu/NiMoP-10, CF@Cu/NiMoP-20, and CF@Cu/NiMoP-40, respectively. The optimal electrodeposition time is found to be 20 min. Therefore, unless otherwise specified, all the data presented in this study are obtained with an electrodeposition time of 20 min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Microstructure and composition The preparation procedure of CF@Cu/NiMoP electrode is illustrated in Fig. 1, which is mainly divided into two steps. The first step is to anodize Cu foam (CF) to in situ form a Cu(OH)2 nanorods array, followed by annealing at 250 °C in air for 2 h to form CuO nanorods array on CF. In the electrochemical oxidation process, CF as the anode continuously loses electrons to produce Cu2+, which combines with OH- to form a vertically oriented Cu(OH)2 nanorods array after increasing the concentration of Cu2+ near the CF surface. In the subsequent high-temperature annealing process, Cu(OH)2 is heated and dehydrated to form structurally stable CuO nanorods array. The Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images showed that the smooth surface of CF was successfully transformed into a three-dimensional open structure CuO nanorods array with a diameter ranging from 150 nm to 300 nm and a length ranging from 6 μm to 10 μm after anodizing and annealing process ( Fig. 2 a and inset). The second step is to use electrochemical deposition technology to uniformly load the NiMoP catalytic layer on the surface of CuO nanorods, which was simultaneously reduced to Cu nanorods array. SEM images showed that the nanorods array structure was not destroyed during electrodeposition (Fig. 2 b and inset) and some bulging particles (marked with red dotted lines) existing on the surface of the nanorods indicate NiMoP film deposition. Moreover, the electrodeposition time has no obvious effect on the array structure of the catalyst (Figure s1). This structural design preserves the three-dimensional skeleton of Cu nanorods array, providing a high specific surface area and high electrical conductivity that is conducive to expose the NiMoP active site. Furthermore, the open channel structure can effectively promote electrolyte diffusion and rapid release of gas products. The NiMoP film layer can also be obtained by electrodeposition of NiMoP directly on the CF (Fig. 2 c and inset), which shows a lower active site density. The catalyst's microstructure, crystal structure, and elemental composition were analyzed using transmission electron microscopy (TEM), selected area electron diffraction (SAED), and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). As shown in Fig. 2 d, TEM images showed that the catalyst presented a nanorod-like structure with a diameter of 200 nm, which was consistent with SEM results. Further observation shows that the rod is formed by nanoparticle assembly. This unique construction not only offers large number of surface-active sites but also maintains good structural stability. The characteristic diffraction rings of (111), (200) (220) and (311) crystal planes corresponding to the cubic Cu phase (JCPDS No. 01–1241) can be identified in the SAED map (Fig. 2 d, inset), which is derived from the reduced copper oxide (Cu) nanorod substrate. It is worth noting that the amorphous layer on the surface of the nanorods is about 4–7 nm thick (Fig. 2 e), which should be classified as the NiMoP layer combined with the characteristics of the electrodeposition process, and its formation mechanism may be related to the obstruction of the ordering of the atomic arrangement during the rapid deposition process. The 0.205 and 0.206 nm lattice spacing match perfectly with the Cu (111) crystal plane (theoretical value 0.208 nm), which also matches the SAED results (Fig. 2 f). In particular, it should be pointed out that a clear heterogeneous interface is formed between the amorphous surface layer and the inner nucleus, and this core-shell structure is conducive to enhancing catalytic activity through interfacial electronic effects. Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) spectrum analysis (Figure s2) confirmed that the catalyst was composed of Cu (68.97 at%), P (0.33 at%), O (24.17 at%), Ni (5.15 at%) and Mo (1.38 at%) (Table s1). The element mapping (Fig. 2 g) further shows that each element presents a continuous and uniform distribution in the axial and radial direction of the microrod, and the spatial distribution of all elements is highly overlapping. The composition and crystalline structure of as-synthesized electrodes were characterized by X-ray diffraction test (XRD). Fig. 3 a displays the XRD patterns of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20, CF@CuO and CF@NiMoP electrodes. All spectra exhibit three major diffraction peaks at 44.5°, 51.9° and 76.4°, corresponding to the (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes of metallic Cu (JCPDS No.04–0850), respectively, which are related to the presence of Cu foam as substrate. For the CF@CuO electrode, the two diffraction peaks at 35.6° and 38.8° belong to the (002) and (111) crystal planes of CuO (JCPDS No.04–0850), respectively. Concurrently, the three peaks observed at 36.7°, 42.6° and 61.4° correspond to the (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes of Cu2+1O, respectively. The results indicate that after anodic oxidation and annealing treatment, the copper oxide nanorods array formed on the surface of copper foam substrate is mainly composed of CuO and Cu2+1O phases. For the CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode, the two diffraction peaks attributed to CuO disappear, and the diffraction peaks attributed to Cu2+1O is much weaker compared with CF@CuO electrode, which indicates that the copper oxide nanorods array is electro-reduced during the cathodic electrodeposition of NiMoP [30]. The nanorods array in CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode is mainly composed of Cu phases, which is conducive to the charge transfer during the catalytic process. In addition, no characteristic diffraction peak of NiMoP phase is observed in the XRD patterns of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode and CF@NiMoP electrode, which indicates that NiMoP prepared by electrodeposition exists in the amorphous state [31]. In order to further determine the chemical state and elemental composition of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted. The survey spectrum shows that only Cu, Mo, Ni, O and P elements exist in the sample (Figure s3), which is consistent with the results of the previous mapping test. The high-resolution spectrum of Cu 2p (Fig. 3 b) shows that the characteristic peaks at 853.2 and 870.3 eV belong to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Cu(0)/Cu(Ⅰ), respectively, which mainly come from Cu formed by electroreduction of copper oxide [32]. The peaks at 856.0 and 873.9 e V a are attributed to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Cu(Ⅱ), accompanied by two satellite peaks at 860.9 and 879.6 e V, respectively. The Cu LMM spectrum was also used to determine the Cu oxidation state. As shown in Figure s4, it was confirmed that Cu0 (568.3 eV) and Cu(I) (570.1 eV) existed in CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode. Notably, the characteristic peak signal of the Cu element in CF@NiMoP (Figure s5a) is lower than that of the CF@Cu/NiMoP-20, possibly because the signal originates from Cu foam but is affected by the electrodeposited NiMoP layer. The high-resolution Ni 2p XPS spectrum of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 is presented in Fig. 3 c. And peaks observed at 781.0 eV and 796.6 eV correspond to Ni(Ⅱ) 2 P3/2 and Ni(Ⅲ) 2 P3/2, respectively. A distinct peak at 778.0 eV is assigned to Niδ+ 2 P3/2 [33]. These findings collectively demonstrate that the Ni element in CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 exists in the form of metal ion as well as metal state. Further analysis of the Mo 3d spectrum of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 (Fig. 3 d) reveals three spin-orbit doublets [34,35]. The first doublet, with binding energies of 228.2 eV and 230.7 eV, is attributed to Moδ+. The remaining doublets at 232.5/235.7 eV and 229.3/233.0 eV are assigned to Mo6+ and Mo4+, respectively, suggesting the presence of multiple molybdenum oxidation states. In the P 2p region (Fig. 3 e), the peaks at 129.4 eV and 130.3 eV are characteristic of Pδ⁻ species, confirming the formation of metal phosphides in CF@Cu/NiMoP-20. The peak at 132.5 eV is attributed to P-O, which may be generated during electrodeposition or by oxidation of the sample in air [33]. The high-resolution spectra of O1s can be fitted to three peaks (Fig. 3 f), corresponding to the metal-oxygen bond (529.9 eV), hydroxyl group (531.0 eV), and oxygen vacancy (532.1 eV), respectively. This indicates that the copper nanorods substrate is rich in oxygen vacancies, which is conducive to the charge transfer and transport during the catalytic process. All these results indicate that bimetallic NiMoP is synthesized successfully. Meanwhile, the XPS spectra of CF@NiMoP (Figure s5b -d) show that the Cu nanorods array substrate has no influence on the chemical state and elemental composition of electrodeposited NiMoP. 3.2 Electrocatalytic HER performance The alkaline HER activity of as-prepared electrodes were explored by using a classical three-electrode system. As shown in Fig. 4 a, whether 0.5 M urea is added to 1.0 M KOH solution has no significant effect on the HER activity of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode, and the overpotential at 100 mA cm−2 increases by only 4 mV after the addition of urea. The LSV curves for all electrodes, including CF@Cu/NiMoP with different deposition time, CF@NiMoP, CF@CuO, bare CF, and Pt/C catalysts, are displayed in Fig. 4 b. The CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode exhibits suprior HER performance with the overpotentials of only 56.3 and 94.9 mV at 20 and 100 mA·cm−2, respectively, which is much lower than that of CF@Cu/NiMoP-40 (57.7/100.4 mV), CF@Cu/NiMoP-10 (68.3/128.9 mV), CF@Cu/NiMoP-5 (121.5/202.5 mV), CF@NiMoP (119.1/190.6 mV), CF@CuO (298.7/413.7 mV), and bare CF (478.9/574.0 mV) (Figure s6). It is worth noting that according to the measured LSV curves, although the overpotential of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode shows a higher overpotential than commercial Pt/C (20.5 mV at 20 mA·cm−2) in the test range, its HER activity tends to exceed that of Pt/C at high current region, so it still has a good application prospect. Not only that, the HER activity of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode is even better than most transition metal-based catalysts reported in the literature (Table s2). Tafel slope, as an important parameter to evaluate catalytic kinetics, can be determined by calculating the slope of the linear region in the Tafel plot. As shown in Fig. 4 c, the Tafel slope of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode is 52.5 mV dec−1, which is only higher than the Tafel slope of the excellent Pt/C catalyst (35.5 mV dec−1), but lower than that of other prepared comparison catalysts, namely CF@Cu/NiMoP-40 (57.4 mV dec−1), CF@Cu/NiMoP-10 (70.0 mV dec−1), CF@Cu/NiMoP-5 (115.7 mV dec−1), CF@NiMoP (108.7 mV dec−1), and CF@CuO (181.1 mV dec−1). Based on the current understanding of HER, this result suggests that the alkaline HER process on CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 surface occurs via the Volmer-Heyrovsky pathway, in which the Volmer step is the rate-determining step [36]. The CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode has an accelerated Volmer step, in other words, the construction of the heterogeneous interface between NiMoP and Cu can promote the dissociation of H2O molecules, thereby increasing the intrinsic catalytic activity of NiMoP. The kinetics toward HER can also be further explored through EIS testing (Figure s7). According to the fitted equivalent circuit (Figure s8), the semicircle diameter of the low frequency region is the charge transfer resistance (R ct) of the catalyst in HER [37,38]. Therefore, CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode exhibits the lowest R ct value of 1.08 Ω, which is lower than other prepared comparison catalysts, including CF@Cu/NiMoP-40 (1.54 Ω), CF@Cu/NiMoP-10 (2.94 Ω), CF@Cu/NiMoP-5 (15.1 Ω), CF@NiMoP (5.00 Ω), CF@CuO (122.6 Ω), and bare CF (401.2 Ω) (Table s3). The ultra-low R ct value of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode indicates that it has excellent charge transfer rate, which is very favorable for reducing HER overpotential, especially at high current density. Of course, the excellent charge transfer rate can be attributed to the formation of oxygen vacancy defects rich CuxO, high-conductive Cu and metal-like NiMoP phases, as well as the close contact of these two components, which improves the electrical conductivity. Next, the intrinsic activity is evaluated by C dl and ECSA, which are calculated by using CV method (Figure s9a -g) by plotting the non-Faraday current against the scanning rate at a certain potential [39]. As shown in Figure s9h, the C dl of as-prepared catalysts is sorted by value as follows: CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 (62.0 mF·cm−2) > CF@Cu/NiMoP-40 (54.9 mF·cm−2) > CF@Cu/NiMoP-10 (52.6 mF·cm−2) > CF@Cu/NiMoP-5 (49.1 mF·cm−2) > CF@CuO (21.1 mF·cm−2) > CF@NiMoP (10.0 mF·cm−2) > bare CF (3.0 mF·cm−2). The increase of C dl in CF@CuO compared with bare CF was attributed to the in-situ growth of CuO nanorods. And the 2.94-fold increase in C dl value after NiMoP electrodeposition should be due to the addition of more exposed active surfaces in the crude NiMoP layer. Obviously, a larger C dl implies a higher ECSA, which can expose more active sites, and a nanorod array structure with more catalyst active surfaces will improve the mass transfer kinetics of the reactants/products. Figure s10 shows the ECSA-normalized LSV curves of as-prepared catalysts toward HER. And the CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode shows obvious performance advantages, which further indicates that it has excellent HER catalytic activity. Stability is one of the important parameters to evaluate the catalytic performance, so the reaction durability of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode was tested. As shown in Fig. 4 d, the activity of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode decreases slightly after 2000 CV cycles in 1 M KOH, and the overpotential required to drive 100 mA cm−2 only increases by 2.8 mV, which proves that the catalyst has outstanding cyclic stability. In addition, a chronoamperometric test (i-t test) is performed on the CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode, and the results showed that the current density remained at 93.9 % of the initial current density after continuous operation for 25 h (Fig. 4 d, inset), indicating that the catalyst has excellent long-term stability. After more than 50 h of long HER electrolysis, the CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode maintained its nanorod array configuration. (Figure s11). Moreover, in the XPS spectrum of Cu 2p after stability test, the characteristic peak of Cu0/Cu1+ still existed significantly (Figure s12a). Meanwhile, the characteristic peaks of Ni0, Pδ- and Moδ+ that appeared respectively in the Ni 2p, P 2p and Mo 3d spectra after HER reaction confirmed the existence of NiMoP (Figure s12b -d). Therefore, it can be determined that the CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode has excellent structural and chemical stability in HER reaction. 3.3 Electrocatalytic UOR performance TMPs is not only an excellent HER catalyst but also can catalyze UOR process [40]. Therefore, the UOR properties of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 and other prepared comparison catalysts were studied. As shown in Fig. 5 a, the CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode has OER activity within the anode potential range in 1.0 M KOH, and its OER potential at 100 mA cm−2 is 1.614 V. In 1.0 M KOH containing 0.5 M urea, the CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 showed UOR activity in the same potential range, and at the same current density of 100 mA cm−2, the UOR potential is about 218 m V better than that of OER, that is, only 1.395 V. This result showed that the CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode exhibits exceptional catalytic activity to UOR, and the observed reduction in potential was attributed to the facile oxidation of urea molecules, highlighting that substituting the OER with UOR as the anode process not only significantly reduces the energy barrier but also enhances hydrogen production efficiency by optimizing the overall reaction thermodynamics. It is worth noting that in the LSV curve of OER, an obvious oxidation peak can be observed in the 1.35–1.45 V interval, which corresponds to the electrochemical oxidation of Ni-based catalyst in alkaline medium, that is, the transformation from Ni2+ to Ni3+, forming the active sites for UOR [41]. The LSV curves in 1.0 M KOH with different concentrations of urea are shown in Figure s13, which indicates that CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode has the best UOR activity in 1.0 M KOH containing 0.5 M urea solution. And the Fig. 5 b shows the LSV curves of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 and other prepared comparison catalysts in 1.0 M KOH containing 0.5 M urea. The driving potentials at 20 and 100 mA cm−2 required by CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 (1.365/1.395 V) are significantly lower than that of CF@NiMoP (1.375/1.451 V), CF@CuO (1.435/1.525 V), bare CF (1.517/1.732 V) and commercial RuO2 (1.459/1.567 V) (Figure s14). The enhanced UOR activity of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20, which are superior to many reported transition metal-based catalysts (Table s2), may be attributable to the NiMoP coated Cu nanorods array structure. In addition, the UOR activity of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 was significantly better than that of CF@Cu/NiMoP-40 (1.374/1.419 V), CF@Cu/NiMoP-10 (1.381/1.451 V) and CF@Cu/NiMoP-5 (1.392/1.502 V), indicating that only the appropriate amount of NiMoP deposition can maximize the exposure of the UOR active site and increase the UOR performance. The LSV curve for UOR normalized by ECSA showed the highest intrinsic activity of CF@NiMoP catalyst (Figure s15), indicating that the high UOR performance of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode comes from the abundant active sites generated by the hierarchical nanorods array structure. In addition, the UOR reaction kinetics were evaluated using the Tafel slope. As shown in Fig. 5 c, the Tafel slope of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 is 28.8 mV dec−1, which is lower than that of CF@Cu/NiMoP-40 (39.3 mV dec−1), CF@Cu/NiMoP-10 (52.1 mV dec−1), CF@Cu/NiMoP-5 (76.9 mV dec−1), CF@NiMoP (45.3 mV dec−1), CF@CuO (119.1 mV dec−1), and RuO2 (85.1 mV dec−1), showing the excellent UOR reaction kinetics of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20. At the same time, EIS curves of as-prepared series electrodes at a voltage of 1.365 V are used to reveal the electron transfer kinetics during electrocatalytic UOR (Figure s16). The fitting parameters listed in Table s4 show that the charge transfer resistance of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 is 3.38 Ω·cm−2, which is lower than that of other comparison samples. It is thus proved that CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode has a fast charge transfer rate and good UOR kinetics, which will help to obtain the best electrocatalytic UOR performance. The potential of the catalyst for practical application to industry largely depends on its stability, which can be assessed through accelerated degradation testing, and chronoamperometric analysis. In the accelerated degradation test, the LSV curve of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode only decreased slightly after 2000 CV cycles, and the potential at 100 mA cm−2 only increased by 7 mV (Fig. 5 d), showing its excellent cyclic stability. Furthermore, CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode has remarkable stability in long-term chronoamperometric experiment, and the current on the CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode remains at 91.7 % of the initial current after 25 h continuous test, indicating that the catalyst has excellent stability in UOR (Fig. 5 d, inset). In addition, the CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode exhibits excellent structural stability while retaining its nanorod array configuration even after undergoing prolonged UOR electrolysis (Figure s17). Moreover, in the XPS spectra of Cu 2p and Ni 2p after stability test, the characteristic peaks of Cu0/Cu1+ and Ni3+ are weakened or disappeared (Figure s18a and b), while the characteristic peaks of Ni3+ at binding energies of 874.6 e V are strengthened (Figure s18b). Since the catalytic reaction is an interfacial reaction, combined with the characterization described above, the NiMoP on electrode surface may undergo electrochemical restructuring during the UOR process, that is, from Ni/Ni2+ to Ni3+. The disappearance of Pδ- and Moδ+ characteristic peaks in the P 2p and Mo 3d spectra after UOR reaction further confirms the NiMoP transformation (Figure s18c and d). Of course, this partial transformation only occurs on the surface of the catalyst, and this high-valent Ni3+ plays an important role in the improvement of UOR activity. 3.4 Overall urea electrolysis performance Considering the excellent HER and UOR performance of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 electrode, a water-urea hybrid electrolytic cell (CF@Cu/NiMoP-20(±)) was constructed, in which CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 was used as both cathode and anode, and 1.0 M KOH containing 0.5 M urea was used as electrolyte. As shown in Figure s19, within a 1.0 M KOH electrolyte containing 0.5 M urea, the overall urea electrolysis system achieves 20 and 100 mA cm−2 at merely 1.499 and 1.596 V, respectively, superior to those of Pt/C||RuO2 (1.520 and 1.741 V). Furthermore, conventional water electrolysis in pure 1.0 M KOH demands significantly higher voltages of 1.665 V and 1.812 V to achieve equivalent current densities ( Fig. 6 a). Notably, the potential disparity between these two systems reaches 216 mV at 100 mA cm−2. This potential gap once again proves that substituting the OER with the thermodynamically favorable UOR can substantially decrease the electrical energy consumption for hydrogen production, thereby lowering operational costs. Therefore, electrolytic urea technology shows practical significance in the field of energy saving and environmental protection. Moreover, the CF@Cu/NiMoP-20(±) system can be easily powered by a commercial 1.5 V mercury-free alkaline batteries (Fig. 6 b). At the same time, the electrolysis voltage of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20(±) at 100 mA cm−2 is comparable to that of the bifunctional catalysts for overall urea electrolysis in recent years (Fig. 6 c), such as coral-like Ni-Mo sulfide: 1.939 V [42]. Cu3P nanowires on Cu foam: 1.79 V [43], Ni, N-codoped NiMoO4: 1.675 V [44], Ni4N/Cu3N nanotubes array: 1.865 V [45], Ni2P-Ni12P5 heterostructure: 1.85 V [46], CoMo oxides@Co on graphite felt: 1.663 V [47], Ru-Doped Fe2TiO5: 1.60 V [48], NiSe-Ni3Se2 Heterojunction: 1.665 V [49]. It is worth mentioning that the CF@Cu/NiMoP-20(±) system can be electrolyzed continuously at a constant cell voltage of 1.5 V in 1.0 M KOH containing 0.5 M urea over 30 h with an initial current density of 492 mA cm−2 and a 14.9 % decrease in current density after test (Fig. 6 d), indicating its excellent stability and potential practical application prospects. Moreover, the Faraday efficiency of urea assisted hydrogen evolution was 97.9 % tested by the water drainage method (Figure s20). 4 Conclusions In summary, a self-supporting CF@Cu/NiMoP electrode consisting of hierarchical Cu/NiMoP nanorods array on copper foam has been successfully developed. As a multifunctional electrode for HER, OER and UOR, the optimal CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 demonstrates remarkable performance with low overpotentials of 94.9 mV (HER) and 384 mV (OER) to achieve 100 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH, while delivering 100 mA cm−2 for UOR in 1.0 M KOH containing 0.5 M urea at a reduced potential of 1.395 V, which is 218 mV lower than its OER counterpart. Furthermore, the electrodes exhibit excellent stability with negligible performance degradation after 50 h of continuous operation as either cathode or anode. The exceptional performance of CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 stems from its hierarchical nanorod array architecture, which provides abundant active sites, facilitates efficient electron transfer, and enables multidirectional transport of electrolytes and gas products. More importantly, the overall urea-electrolysis system with CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 as bifunctional catalyst affords 100 mA cm−2 at a cell voltage of 1.596 V, operable using commercial mercury-free alkaline batteries. Hence, this study will provide a simple method for designing high-performance HER/UOR bifunctional electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: The development of bifunctional electrocatalyst for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and urea oxidation reaction (UOR) with high catalytic activity and excellent stability can promote the application of hydrogen production by urea electrolysis. In this work, a three-dimensional composite heterogeneous electrocatalyst composed of NiMoP coating on Cu nanorods array on Cu foam (CF@Cu/NiMoP) is designed and synthesized. The CuO nanorods array constructed on Cu foam was used as the substrate for electrodeposition of NiMoP layer, while CuO substrate was reduced to Cu nanorods. The optimal deposition time was 20 min in both HER and UOR processes. Because the hierarchical nanorods array structure offers abundant active sites, accelerates electron transfer kinetics, and enables efficient multi-channel transport of electrolytes and gaseous byproducts, the optimized CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 has excellent HER and UOR performances with requiring only −94.9 mV and 1.395 V, respectively, to drive 100 mA cm−2. In addition, the overall urea-electrolysis system with CF@Cu/NiMoP-20 as bifunctional electrode provides 100 mA cm−2 at a remarkably low cell voltage of 1.596 V. This energy-efficient performance can be readily powered by a commercially available mercury-free alkaline battery.
